author: Deleted User
content: Not sure if I can make it to the meeting, but if you ask me, these would be my initial personal opinions. EIP-2315 - not to be considered for London, because there are still lots of things to work out there about validation. Also, these changes do require full cooperation with compiler teams, because the roll-out plan will require core devs and compiler devs to make changes in lock-step. So inclusion of "reborn" EIP-2315 is still premature. BLS Support as a precompile - I still think evm384 is a better solution to the underlying problem and needs to be pursued instead. Sponsored Transaction Precompile - not to include to London - is there a way to do it without precompile (these are ugly things and should not be regarded as normal artefacts of EVM development), also consider who exactly will need it and what are the alternatives. BEGINDATA - proposal looks simple enough, but I would prefer to first look at a more general proposal from <@!425279588009246720> that proposes the introduction of code formats. If the more general approach is found too complex, I would consider including BEGINDATA. Limiting size of initcode - I would say yes, this looks trivial but I would like to hear more about benefits

author: holiman
content:
Imo

- 2315 should not be included. The 'reborn' is same as previous. It is a Feature-eip, and adding any features need to be backed solidly by showing that there is a demand for the feature. As neither Vyper nor Solodity demands/wants it, I don't see why we would include it. 
- 3074 Should not be included. It's still iterated on, and the semantics are very hard to overview. The possible quirks with new call types are _many_ both on infra layer and app layer, and I think it needs more time to be fully understood. 
- 2327 Begindata: imo also too soon/rushed. In it's current form, it's not ideal, IMO, and could be done better. 
- bls precompiles - not sure. I'm slightly in favor of it over 384 right now, but I'm on the fence. 

Only my 5 cents, fwiw.

author: gcolvin
content:
A suggestion -- <@!187490121698770945>, <@!552133098075193354> -- if London really is premature:

We now have several EVM-related proposals on the table.  EIP-1051, EIP-2315, EIP-2327, EIP-3336, and EIP 3337 among them.  Would it make sense to form a working group of their authors -- <@!307777296406806529> <@!211091239112671234> <@!194433073394352129> --- and other interested parties and plan a single post-London upgrade containing all and only EVM-related proposals?

author: timbeiko
content:
I think this is a good idea, yes! I feel like we should only have one "big EIP" or "theme" per upgrade, and while we may want to add a few small tweaks alongside it, we should try and focus on one thing, ship it, and then ship whatever next "big thing" is ready. 

I'd be weary of committing to which "theme" is for which upgrade before the work is nearly done, though. For example, right now we could have the merge work and EVM work both happening in working groups in parallel. If the merge is ready first, we should ship that (and only commit to it when it is reasonably ready), and vice-versa for the EVM work.

author: timbeiko
content: <@!489256758989029405> raised this on the previous ACD w.r.t. London & 1559. I generally agree we should try and limit London's scope to 1559 and related EIPs (i.e. removing gas refunds), or very small changes. Otherwise, we risk (and usually end up) delaying the upgrade for another "big thing" that's not ready.

author: gcolvin
content:
My take is that the EVM  EIPs I mentioned are very nearly ready technically -- or else shouldn't go in yet. And those which have not been implemented already are not difficult to implement.  So I think we are looking at only a few months.

I don't know when "the merge" is supposed to happen, but I think the work is largely independent.

author: timbeiko
content:
So, if they are "nearly ready", then I suspect the fork after London makes sense. Reading above, it seems like what Alexey and Martin want to see is more user validation that the work will bring benefits. 

Re: the Merge, agreed it is independent, and it is much earlier in terms of readiness. Assuming EVM is ready before, we should ship that, but if they are both ready at the same time, I still think it is best to ship two distinct forks each of which has a more narrow focus.
